repnme.cdata!:
Armenia - Access to Finance for Small and
            Medium Enterprises Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Access to Finance for
            Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs') Project for
            Armenia were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was moderate; Bank performance was
            satisfactory and borrower performance was also satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned includes: Project Development
            Objectives (PDO) for addressing a development priority
            should be kept realistic. The PDO of maintaining or
            improving SMEs' access to medium term finance was kept
            simple and realistic. Onerous safeguard and fiduciary
            requirements slow down project implementation. Reevaluating
            safeguard and fiduciary requirements in the context of
            credit lines and designing information requirements to
            minimize compliance costs, while serving the safeguard
            objectives, will help ensure successful implementation. A
            solid monitoring and evaluation framework helps demonstrate
            the sustainability and long-term impact of credit lines.
            Flexibility during project design and implementation is
            critical to successful outcomes. As noted, the flexibility
            of changing some procurement procedures made a difference in
            speeding up project implementation. Significant capacity
            building of the Project Implementation Unit (PIU) and
            Participating Financial Institutions (PFIs) to comply with
            the project's requirements is essential before the
            project begins and early in its implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Armenia - Access to Finance for Small and
            Medium Enterprises Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Access
            to Finance for Small and Medium Enterprises Project is to
            maintain or increase Armenian small and medium
            enterprises' access to medium term finance. The closing
            date for the project will be extended from September 28,
            2011 until December 31, 2012.  The extension is necessary to
            absorb all the funds without lowering the quality of
            participating banks' portfolios and will further
            reinforce the project outcomes, inter alia, expanding
            financial intermediation with growth in Small and Medium
            Enterprises (SME) credit lines as a share of total credit.
            This will be the first extension of the project.

display_title.display_title:
Armenia - Access to Finance for
            Small and Medium Enterprises Project : restructuring  (Vol.
            2) : Data sheet

repnme.cdata!:
Armenia - Access to Finance for Small and
            Medium Enterprises Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objective of the Access to
            Finance for Small and Medium Enterprises is to support the
            development of Armenia's small and medium-scale rural
            businesses by improving the ability of farmers and rural
            entrepreneurs to access markets and by stimulating
            market-oriented private and public investments in rural
            areas. The project consists of four components to be
            implemented over four years. The major focus will be to
            support the continued development of commercial activities
            in the rural areas by improving market linkages, product
            quality, competitiveness and capacity of Armenian rural
            entrepreneurs and producers. The project will have a
            three-tiered approach by addressing critical gaps at the
            farm level, at the community level, and at the rural
            business and agro processor level. Regarding investment
            financing, the project provides resources for on-lending to
            farmers and farmer groups, agro-processors, and other
            agri-businesses through qualifying Participating Financial
            Institutions (PFIs).
